Tesla traded at $430.17 this Friday November 28th, increasing $3.59 or 0.84 percent since the previous trading session. Looking back, over the last four weeks, Tesla gained 6.79 percent. Over the last 12 months, its price rose by 24.69 percent. Looking ahead, we forecast Tesla to be priced at 416.62 by the end of this quarter and at 378.48 in one year, according to Trading Economics global macro models projections and analysts expectations.... Title: __symbol__ Stock Quote Price and Forecast | CNN
URL: https://www.cnn.com/markets/stocks/TSLA
Snippet: ### Key terms
## About TSLA
Tesla, Inc. engages in the design, development, manufacture, and sale of electric vehicles and energy generation and storage systems. It operates through the Automotive and Energy Generation and Storage segments. The Automotive segment includes the design, development, manufacture, sale, and lease of electric vehicles as well as sales of automotive regulatory credits.... The Energy Generation and Storage segment is involved in the design, manufacture, installation, sale, and lease of solar energy generation, energy storage products, and related services and sales of solar energy systems incentives. The company was founded by Jeffrey B. Straubel, Elon Reeve Musk, Martin Eberhard, and Marc Tarpenning on July 1, 2003 and is headquartered in Austin, TX.

Title: Tesla Stock’s Worst Year Ever, Explained | WSJ
URL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nZvBB1HVe4Q
Snippet: ## The Wall Street Journal
##### Jan 06, 2023 (0:05:47)
Tesla closed its worst year in its stock’s history, shedding about $675 billion in market valuation in 2022—the same year CEO Elon Musk bought Twitter. But reasons for the selloff go well beyond the social media company. WSJ’s Sean McLain explains.

Photo illustration: Amber Bragdon/Getty Images

#Tesla #ElonMusk #WSJ... (all laughing)
{ts:14} - [Narrator] Since the deals
closed in late October, Tesla shares have slipped
ending the year down 65%. The company's worst year on record.
{ts:21} But the reason for the selloff
goes far beyond Twitter. Here's what drove Tesla... investors away in 2022, and what's affecting the
car maker going into 2023.
{ts:31} Let's start with demand. For years, Tesla has
stood out as the leader in the electric vehicle space,
{ts:37} and while its dominance continued in the third quarter of 2022, its market share slipped to 61%.... {ts:58} - [Narrator] According to JD Power, there were 33 EV models
available in the US at the end of 2021, but by the end of 2022
{ts:66} that number had jumped to 53 models. Tesla still held four of the top five selling... EVs last year according
{ts:73} to S&P Global Mobility. But the sell-off in Tesla shares reflects investors' fear
that its hold won't last
{ts:80} as newer models arrive. - Tesla has sold the same
sort of handful of models for years now, and the question is... {ts:86} will Tesla continue to be as competitive as it has in the past or
will they become outdated? - [Narrator] Further fueling concerns
{ts:93} are customer wait times for Tesla cars, which dropped sharply over 2022. Some investors see this as a sign
{ts:100} demand is already softening.... Musk addressed these concerns on Tesla's third quarter earnings call.
{ts:105} - [Musk] I can't emphasize enough. We have excellent demand for Q4, and we expect to sell
every car that we make
{ts:116} as far into the future as we can see. - [Narrator] And in December, the CEO said on a Twitter Spaces call... that demand pressures
{ts:122} were driven by rising
interest rate policies. Production disruptions also contributed to the stock slide last year
{ts:129} leading to Tesla missing its full year vehicle delivery target. The EV makers said it
delivered 1.3 million vehicles
{ts:136} in 2022, up 40% from 2021.... That was shy of its goal
of increasing deliveries by 50% or more.
{ts:143} It would've needed more than
1.4 million to hit that target. News of the shortfall pushed stocks down another 12% to start the new year.
{ts:152} Its largest single day decline... in more than two years. Intermittent factory closures at Tesla's China plant,
its largest by volume,
{ts:159} were one part of the problem. - China's zero COVID policy led to a number of shutdowns
at its factory in Shanghai,
{ts:165} which obviously created
supply issues of its own. - [Narrator] Tesla also... mover in that market. Its valuation was driven
in part by its CEO
{ts:257} and some investors say Musk's promises about future vehicles
have pushed shares higher though many of the cars
didn't come until years later.
{ts:266} The latest example, Tesla's cyber truck, which was first unveiled three years ago and still hasn't hit the market.... {ts:272} - Cyber truck is gonna be awesome. It's worth the wait. Believe me. - [Narrator] And more directly,
{ts:277} Musk's move to offload
billions in Tesla stock in part related to Twitter, has pushed down Tesla's share price.
{ts:283} - Anytime anybody sells $40... third quarter earnings call, Musk said that he sees the EV company as recession resilient.
{ts:324} - [Musk] Let's say 2023 is
a brutal recession year. Even then, we generate meaningful cash. - [Narrator] Tesla investors
are now waiting for later
{ts:334} this month when the car maker will report its full year earnings,... which could give a glimpse of the stock's prospects
for the coming year.
{ts:340} (upbeat music)

1. Tesla experienced a significant decline in stock value in 2022, dropping nearly 67%. (Source: Wall Street Journal)
2. The decline was attributed to various factors, including increased competition and production issues. (Source: Wall Street Journal)
3. Current trends in 2023 show a dramatic recovery, with over 100% gains. (Source: StatMuse)
4. Tesla's stock had its worst year in history in 2022 with a market valuation loss of $675 billion. (Source: Wall Street Journal)
5. Investors are now optimistic as the stock continues to rebound in 2023.

segments.title: A Year of Ups and Downs
segments.text: The year 2022 was a rollercoaster for Tesla's stock. After soaring to great heights, the company faced challenges that led to its steepest decline in history. Investors watched as the stock plummeted by nearly 67% amidst fears of stiffening competition, production issues, and even outside distractions, like CEO Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter. Despite the turmoil, 2023 has shown signs of a bounce back with over 100% gains so far. Will Tesla reclaim its former glory? Only time will tell...
